{{other people|Swami Dayananda}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = [[dom (title)|Dom]] Bede Griffiths OSB Cam |image = Bedegriffiths.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Alan Richard Griffiths |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1906|12|17}} |birth_place = [[Walton-on-Thames]], Surrey, England |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1993|05|13|1906|12|17}} |death_place = Shantivanam, [[Tamil Nadu]], India |nationality = English, Indian |other_names = Swami Dayananda |known_for = [[Integral thought]] |education = |alma_mater = [[Magdalen College, Oxford]] |employer = |occupation = [[Camaldolese]] [[monk]], [[Mysticism|mystic]], theologian |years_active = }}
'''Bede Griffiths''' [[Camaldolese|OSB Cam]]<ref>[http://www.osb.org/new/2001-2005/0504new.html Order of St Benedict website]</ref> (17 December 1906 – 13 May 1993), born '''Alan Richard Griffiths''' and also known by the end of his life as '''Swami Dayananda''' ("bliss of compassion"), was a British-born [[Benedictine]] [[monk]] and priest who lived in [[ashram]]s in South India and became a noted [[yogi]]. He became a leading thinker in the development of the dialogue between Christianity and [[Hinduism]]. Griffiths was a part of the [[Christian Ashram Movement]].
==Biography==
===Early years=== Griffiths was born in [[Walton-on-Thames]], Surrey, England, at the end of 1906, the youngest of three children of a middle-class family. Shortly after Griffiths' birth, his father was betrayed by a business partner and was left penniless. His mother took the children and established residence in a smaller home which she maintained, though she had to find work to support herself and the children. At age 12, Griffiths was sent to [[Christ's Hospital]], a school for poor boys.<ref name="Bede">{{cite news|last1=Fastiggi|first1=Robert|last2=Pereira|first2=Jose|title=The Sawmi from Oxford|url=http://www.bedegriffiths.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/The-Swami-from-Oxford.pdf|accessdate=20 October 2017|work=Crisis|issue=March 1991|date=1991}}</ref> The students of this school were nicknamed "bluecoats". He excelled in his studies and earned a scholarship to the [[University of Oxford]] where, in 1925, he began his studies in English literature and philosophy at [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]]. In his third year at university he came under the tutelage of [[C. S. Lewis]], who became a lifelong friend. Griffiths graduated from Oxford in 1929 with a degree in journalism.
Shortly after graduation Griffiths, with fellow Oxford alumni [[Martyn Skinner]] and Hugh Waterman, settled in a cottage in the [[Cotswold]]s and began what they called an "experiment in common living".<ref>The golden string. 1954</ref> They followed a lifestyle attuned to nature, milking cows and selling the milk to support themselves. They would read the Bible together as a form of literature. Griffiths noted a strong connection between the teachings of [[Scripture]] and the rhythm of the nature around them. The experiment lasted less than a year, as one of the friends found the life too demanding. Nevertheless, the experience had a strong effect on Griffiths.
As a result of this experience, Griffiths decided to seek [[Holy Orders]] in the [[Church of England]]. He was advised, however, to gain some experience in the slums of London. This advice was so contrary to what Griffiths felt to be his [[vocation]] that it drove him to a crisis of faith, which nearly drove him to an emotional breakdown.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} Guided by the writings of [[Cardinal Newman]], he reached a point in this struggle where he had a spiritual breakthrough. He recounts the story of his conversion in his autobiography ''The Golden String''.
In November 1931, Griffiths went to stay at the [[Order of St. Benedict|Benedictine]] [[monastery]] of [[Prinknash Abbey]] where he was impressed by the life. Despite the strong anti-Roman Catholic sentiments of his mother, he was received into the Roman Catholic Church and made his [[First Communion]] at Christmas Eve [[mass (liturgy)|Mass]] at the abbey.
===Benedictine monastic life=== Griffiths was received by the abbey as a [[postulant]] a month after his reception into the Catholic Church. On 29 December 1932, he entered the [[novitiate]] and was given the monastic name of "Bede". He made his solemn [[profession]] in 1937 (a year before the death of his mother in a car accident) and was [[ordained]] to the [[Catholic priesthood]] in 1940.
In 1947 the abbey sent a group of 25 monks to give support to two monasteries in the United Kingdom which had been founded by monks from France. Griffiths was chosen to be the [[prior|obedientiary prior]] for the monastery at [[St Michael's Abbey, Farnborough|Farnborough]] in Hampshire. He led that house for four years, but was unable to generate sufficient financial support to keep the community going. The abbot then sent him to the other monastery, [[Pluscarden Abbey]] in Scotland. It was there that he wrote his autobiography.
During Griffiths' time at Farnborough, he had come to know Father Benedict Alapatt, a European-born monk of Indian descent who was greatly interested in establishing a monastery in his homeland. Griffiths had already been introduced to Eastern thought, [[yoga]] and the [[Vedas]] and took interest in this proposed project. The abbot at first refused permission, but later changed his mind and authorised Griffiths to go to India with the Indian member of the community. There was one condition, though: Griffiths was not to be there as a member of the abbey, but as a priest subject to a local bishop, which meant that he would be giving up his vows.
===Christian yogi=== After some painful inner debate, Griffiths agreed to this and, in 1955, he embarked for India with Alapatt. At the time, he wrote to a friend: "I am going to discover the other half of my soul."{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} After arriving and visiting some spiritual centres in the country, they settled in [[Kengeri]] in [[Bangalore, India|Bangalore]], considered{{by whom|date=November 2011}} the garden spot of India, with the goal of building a monastery there. That project was eventually unsuccessful as Griffiths left the location in 1958, saying that he found it "too Western".<ref>{{cite web|title=Man, monk, mystic|first=Sister Pascaline, OSB|last=Coff|work=The Bede Griffiths Trust|url=http://www.bedegriffiths.com/bede-griffiths/}}</ref>
Griffiths then joined with a [[Belgian people|Belgian]] monk, Father [[Francis Acharya]], [[Trappists|OCSO]], to establish [[Kristiya Sanyasa Samaj,Kurisumala Ashram|Kristiya Sanyasa Samaj, Kurisumala Ashram]] ("Mountain of the Cross"), a [[Syriac Christianity|Syriac Rite]] monastery of the [[Syro-Malankara Catholic Church]] in Kerala. They sought to develop a form of monastic life based in the Indian tradition, adopting the [[saffron]] garments of an Indian ''[[sannyasi]]'' (an [[ascetic]] or monk). At that point, Griffiths took the [[Sanskrit]] name "'''Dayananda'''" ("bliss of compassion"). During that time he continued his studies in the religions and cultures of India, writing ''Christ in India'' while there. He also visited the United States during the period, giving a number of talks about East–West dialogue and being interviewed by [[CBS]] television.
Later, in 1968, Griffiths moved to the [[Saccidananda Ashram]] (also known as ''Shantivanam''; [[Tamil language|Tamil]] for "forest of peace") in [[Tamil Nadu]], South India,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bedegriffiths.com/ashrams/ |work=The Bede Griffiths Trust |title=Saccidananda Ashram |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613061415/http://www.bedegriffiths.com/ashrams/ |archivedate=13 June 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> which had been founded in 1950 by the French Benedictine monk [[Abhishiktananda]] (Dom Henri Le Saux, OSB), from the [[Abbey of Kergonan]], along with another Frenchman, the [[Abbé]] Jules Monchanin. The two had developed a religious lifestyle which was completely expressed in authentic Indian fashion, using English, Sanskrit and [[Tamil language|Tamil]] in their religious services. They had built the ashram buildings by hand in the style of the poor of the country. Monchanin had died in 1957 and Le Saux wanted to devote himself to a [[hermit]]'s life. Griffiths came with two other monks to assume life there and to allow Le Saux his wish.
Griffiths resumed his studies of Indian thought, trying to relate it to Christian theology. At this point, he became known as "'''Swami Dayananda'''" ("bliss of compassion"). He wrote 12 books on [[Hindu]]–Christian dialogue. During this period, Griffiths desired to reconnect himself with the Benedictine order and sought a monastic [[congregation (Catholic)|congregation]] which would accept him in the way of life he had developed over the decades. He was welcomed by the [[Camaldolese]] monks, and he and the ashram became a part of their congregation.
===Final years=== In January 1990, Griffiths suffered a stroke in his room at the ashram. A month later, to the day, he was declared healed. The following year, he began a period of extensive travel, making annual visits to the United States, then later to Europe, where he met the [[Dalai Lama]]. He noted to a friend, "I do believe that he liked me."<ref>"Bede Griffiths:Meeting the Dalai Lama" by Meath Conlin on his website, Diverse Journeys, 22 June 2010 [http://diversejourneys.com/?p=1214]</ref> He continued his journey, giving lectures in Germany and England. He arrived back at the ashram in October 1992, where an Australian film crew were awaiting him to make a documentary about his life, which was released as ''A Human Search''.
Three days after the completion of filming, on his 86th birthday, Griffiths had a major stroke. The following month, he had a further series of strokes. He died at Shantivanam on 13 May 1993, aged 86.
==Legacy== The archives of the Bede Griffiths Trust are located at the [[Graduate Theological Union]] in [[Berkeley, California]]. His contributions are promoted and developed by the Bede Griffiths Trust and by the Camaldolese Institute for East–West Dialogue based at the American Camaldolese hermitage of [[New Camaldoli]], located in [[Big Sur]], California.<ref>[http://www.bedegriffiths.com/camaldolese-institute/ Bede Griffiths' Trust website]</ref>
==Bibliography==
===Primary=== *''The Golden String: An Autobiography'', (1954), Templegate Publishers, 1980 edition: {{ISBN|0-87243-163-0}}, Medio Media, 2003: {{ISBN|0-9725627-3-7}} *''Christ in India: Essays Towards a Hindu-Christian Dialogue'' (1967), Templegate Publishers, 1984, {{ISBN|0-87243-134-7}} *''Return to the Center'', (1976), Templegate Publishers, 1982, {{ISBN|0-87243-112-6}} *''Marriage of East and West: A Sequel to The Golden String'', Templegate Publishers, 1982, {{ISBN|0-87243-105-3}} *''Cosmic Revelation: The Hindu Way to God'', Templegate Publishers, 1983, {{ISBN|0-87243-119-3}} *''A New Vision of Reality: Western Science, Eastern Mysticism and Christian Faith'', Templegate Publishers, 1990, {{ISBN|0-87243-180-0}} *''River of Compassion: A Christian Commentary on the Bhagavad Gita'', (1987), Element Books, 1995 reprint: {{ISBN|0-8264-0769-2}} *''Bede Griffiths'', Templegate Publishers, 1993, {{ISBN|0-87243-199-1}} *''The New Creation in Christ: Christian Meditation and Community'', Templegate Publishers, 1994, {{ISBN|0-87243-209-2}} *(co-editor with Roland R. Ropers), ''Psalms for Christian Prayer'', Harpercollins, 1996, {{ISBN|0-00-627956-2}} *John Swindells (editor), ''A Human Search: Bede Griffiths Reflects on His Life: An Oral History'', Triumph Books, 1997, {{ISBN|0-89243-935-1}} (from 1992 Australian television documentary) *Bruno Barnhart, O.S.B. Cam. (editor), ''The One Light: Bede Griffiths' Principal Writings'', Templegate Publishers, 2001, {{ISBN|0-87243-254-8}} *Thomas Matus, O.S.B. Cam. (editor), ''Bede Griffiths: Essential Writings'', Orbis Books, 2004, {{ISBN|1-57075-200-1}} *"The Relation of Ultimate Truth to the Life of the World." Ernakulam: Lumen Institute, 1964. *''Christian Ashram: Essays towards a Hindu-Christian Dialogue''. London: DLT, 1966. 249 pp.
===Secondary=== * Kathryn Spink, ''A Sense of the Sacred: A Biography of Bede Griffiths'', Orbis Books, 1989. {{ISBN|0-88344-442-9}} * Beatrice Bruteau (ed.), ''The Other Half of My Soul: Bede Griffiths and the Hindu-Christian Dialogue'', Quest Books, 1996. {{ISBN|0-8356-0717-8}} (Essays in honour of Griffiths by [[Matthew Fox (priest)|Matthew Fox]], [[Thomas Keating]], [[Rupert Sheldrake]], [[Thomas Berry]], Judson Trapnell, [[Wayne Teasdale]], and others). * Jesu Rajan, ''Bede's Journey to the Beyond'', Bangalore, India: Asian Trading Corporation, 1997. {{ISBN|81-7086-211-6}} * Judson B. Trapnell, ''Bede Griffiths. A Life of Dialogue'', Albany: State University of New York Press (SUNY Press), 2001. (Collection: SUNY Series in Religious Studies). {{ISBN|0-7914-4871-1}} * [[Wayne Teasdale]], ''Bede Griffiths: An Introduction to His Interspiritual Thought'', Skylight Paths Publishing, 2003. {{ISBN|1-893361-77-2}} * [[Shirley du Boulay]], ''Beyond the Darkness: A Biography of Bede Griffiths'', Alresford, UK: O Books, 2003. {{ISBN|1-903816-16-5}}. * Albano Fernandes, ''The Hindu Mystical Experience: A Comparative Study of the Approaches of [[R. C. Zaehner]] and Bede Griffiths''. New Delhi, India: Intercultural Publications, 2004. * [[Dion Forster]], [http://www.spirituality.org.za/Aspects%20of%20the%20cosmic%20Christ%20in%20the%20spirituality%20of%20Dom%20Bede%20Griffithsf.pdf ''Christ at the centre: Discovering the Cosmic Christ in the spirituality of Bede Griffiths'']. Kempton Park: AcadSA Publishers, 2008. {{ISBN|978-1-920212-24-7}}. * [[Pandikattu]], Kuruvilla, ''Religious dialogue as hermeneutics: Bede Griffith's advaitic approach to religions, Cultural heritage and contemporary change''. (Series IIIB, South Asia). Washington, D.C.: Council for Research in Values and Philosophy, 2001. {{ISBN|1-56518-139-5}}. Available [https://books.google.com/books?id=Kg8eZgjFBxcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Pandikattu,+Kuruvilla.+2001.+Religious+dialogue+as+hermeneutics+:+Bede+Griffith%27s+advaitic+approach+to+religions,+isbn&source=bl&ots=7mYGfo9h9_&sig=R7hm4uZYKkTL1tklBJUsY5escQY&hl=en&ei=SGYlTcCEMcnmrAfOt-30DA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false online]. *Ivo Coelho and Banzelao Julio Teixeira, "Review of Albano Fernandes, ''The Hindu Mystical Experience: A Comparative Study of the Approaches of R. C. Zaehner and Bede Griffiths''". ''[[Divyadaan: Journal of Philosophy and Education]]'' 17/1 (2006) 109–112.

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{original research|date=January 2013}} {{Cleanup rewrite|date=March 2016}} }} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Vampirism | synonyms = Renfield's syndrome, Renfield syndrome | image = | caption = | pronounce = | field = [[Psychiatry]] | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Clinical vampirism''', more commonly known as '''Renfield's syndrome''' or '''Renfield syndrome''', is an obsession with drinking [[blood]]. The earliest formal presentation of clinical vampirism to appear in the psychiatric literature, with the psychoanalytic interpretation of two cases, was contributed by Richard L. Vanden Bergh and John F. Kelley in 1964.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Vanden Bergh|first=Richard L.|author2=Kelley, John F.|title=Vampirism -- A review with new observations|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|year=1964|volume=11|pages=543–547|doi=10.1001/archpsyc.1964.01720290085012|pmid=14208658}}</ref> As the authors point out, brief and sporadic reports of blood-drinking behaviors associated with sexual pleasure have appeared in the psychiatric literature at least since 1892 with the work of Austrian forensic psychiatrist [[Richard von Krafft-Ebing]]. Many medical publications concerning clinical vampirism can be found in the literature of forensic psychiatry, with the unusual behavior reported as one of many aspects of extraordinary violent crimes.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hemphill|first=R.E.|author2=Zabow, T.|title=Clinical vampirism: A presentation of 3 cases and a reevaluation of Haigh, the "Acid-Bath Murderer"|journal=South African Medical Journal|year=1983|volume=63|pages=278–281.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Jaffe|first=PD|author2=DiCataldo, F.|title=Clinical vampirism: blending myth and reality|journal=Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and Law|year=1994|volume=22|issue=4|pages=533–544}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ramsland|first=Katharine|title=The Vampire Killers|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/weird/vampires/1.html|publisher=Crime Library|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121210092523/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/weird/vampires/1.html|archive-date=10 December 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== History ==
The syndrome is named after [[Dracula]]'s human zoophagous follower, [[Renfield|R. M. Renfield]], in the 1897 novel by [[Bram Stoker]]. According to an interview conducted by psychology professor [[Katherine Ramsland]] with clinical psychologist [[Richard Noll]], who coined the eponymous term in a 1992 book,<ref>{{cite book | author=[[Richard Noll]] | title=Vampires, Werewolves and Demons: twentieth century reports in the psychiatric literature | publisher=Brunner/Mazel Publications | year=1992 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tVkfHgAACAAJ&dq |isbn=0-87630-632-6}},https://www.academia.edu/6793535/Vampires_Werewolves_and_Demons_Twentieth_Century_Case_Reports_in_the_Psychiatric_Literature_1991_</ref> he invented the term and its purported diagnostic criteria as a whimsical parody of the "new DSM-speak" of the psychiatry of the 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ramsland|first=Katharine|title=Vampire Personality Disorder|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/shadow-boxing/201211/vampire-personality-disorder|publisher=Psychology Today (21 November 2012)|accessdate=2 March 2013}}</ref> In a public lecture hosted by Penn State University's Institute for the Arts and Humanities on 7 October 2013, Noll traced the 20-year trajectory of his unintentionally created "monster" from the moment of its creation as a parody of DSM mental disorders to the cultural popularity of Renfield's syndrome today.<ref>{{cite web|last=Penn State University Institute for the Arts and Humanities|title=Events Schedule, October 2013|url=http://www.iah.psu.edu/archive/allevents.shtml|accessdate=10 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130914194410/http://iah.psu.edu/archive/allevents.shtml|archive-date=14 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/268278489_Renfield's_Syndrome_or_How_I_(Unintentionally)_Created_a_Monster?ev=prf_pub|title=Renfield's Syndrome, or, How I (Unintentionally) Created a Monster|website=ResearchGate|date=October 2013|author=Richard Noll|access-date=2017-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304032407/https://www.researchgate.net/publication/268278489_Renfield's_Syndrome_or_How_I_(Unintentionally)_Created_a_Monster?ev=prf_pub|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
After Noll's book appeared in the year 1992 clinical vampirism has usually been referred to as Renfield's syndrome. In an NBC pre-Halloween special hosted by actor Peter Graves entitled "The Unexplained: Witches, Werewolves and Vampires" that aired on 23 October 1994 (and is available on YouTube, with the 34:11 mark beginning the segment), pages from Noll's book were shown on camera as Canadian psychologist [[Leonard George]] summarized Renfield's syndrome for a wide television audience.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Unexplained: Witches, Werewolves and Demons|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2sQN7VpdX4s|publisher=You Tube|accessdate=2 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609000940/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2sQN7VpdX4s|archive-date=9 June 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Elias|first=Thomas D.|title=Television: "The Unexplained" Just the Latest Chapter in Peter Graves' Career|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-10-22/entertainment/9410220048_1_show-business-strange-stories-fun|publisher=Chicago Tribune, 22 October 1994|accessdate=2 March 2013|date=22 October 1994|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610205331/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-10-22/entertainment/9410220048_1_show-business-strange-stories-fun|archive-date=10 June 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Characters suffering from Renfield's Syndrome have appeared on television. The first appeared in a 2005 episode of ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|CSI]]'' titled "Committed" (Season 5, Episode 21).<ref>{{cite news|title=CSI:Committed |url=http://www.cbs.com/primetime/csi/episodes/520 |quote=Kenny Valdez is in the Seclusion Room, strapped to a bed in a five-point restraint system, claiming he can "smell it!" Kenny suffers from Renfield's syndrome, a self-mutilator. The CSIs notice that even though Kenny has blood on his clothes, there is no spatter pattern. |publisher=[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]] |accessdate=2007-12-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228042908/http://www.cbs.com/primetime/csi/episodes/520 |archivedate=2008-02-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=cl/> It was also mentioned in 2009 in episode 7, season 5 of ''Criminal Minds'' entitled "The Performer".<ref>{{cite web|last=CBS|title=Criminal Minds show homepage|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/criminal_minds/season/5/episodes/|accessdate=12 July 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611220100/http://www.cbs.com/shows/criminal_minds/season/5/episodes/|archive-date=11 June 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2010 an 11-episode Canadian television series, ''The Renfield Syndrome'', was filmed in Vancouver, B.C., but does not seem to have been aired.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Renfield Syndrome (2010)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1764036/|accessdate=1 September 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406092302/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1764036/|archive-date=6 April 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 15 August 2012 Renfield's syndrome was the subject of a video segment on ''The Huffington Post'' by Cara Santa Maria which again relied heavily on Noll's work and a recent scholarly article on the (pseudo-)syndrome published in the ''Journal of the History of the Neurosciences''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Santa Maria|first=Cara|authorlink=Cara Santa Maria|title=Renfield's Syndrome: A Mysterious Case of Real-Life Vampirism|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/15/renfields-syndrome-vampirism_n_1765799.html|publisher=The Huffington Post (15 August 2012)|accessdate=2 March 2013|date=15 August 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325171428/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/15/renfields-syndrome-vampirism_n_1765799.html|archive-date=25 March 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Olry|first=Regis|author2=Duane E. Haines|title=Renfield's Syndrome: A Psychiatric Illness Drawn from Bram Stoker's Dracula|journal=Journal of the History of the Neurosciences|year=2011|volume=20|pages=368–371|doi=10.1080/0964704x.2011.595655}}</ref>
In addition to references to Renfield's syndrome in the psychiatric literature and mass media, the horror writer Chelsea Quinn Yarbro published a story entitled "Renfield's Syndrome" in July 2002, which was then reprinted in an anthology that appeared the following year.<ref>{{cite book|last=Yarbro|first=chelsea Quinn|title=Apprehensions and Other Delusions|year=2003|publisher=Five Star|location=Waterville, Maine}}</ref> It is also the title of a novel by J.A. Saare.<ref>{{cite web|last=Saare|first=J.A.|title=The Renfield Syndrome|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Renfield-Syndrome-ebook/dp/B005IEIJY2|accessdate=1 Sep 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712041049/http://www.amazon.com/The-Renfield-Syndrome-ebook/dp/B005IEIJY2|archive-date=12 July 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The twenty-year evolution of a farcical 3-page book section that shot through the mass media and then—uncritically—into the pages of a peer-reviewed scholarly journal should serve as a cautionary tale about the purported validity of other "mental disorders." Philosopher of science Ian Hacking refers to this process as "making up people" and critiques medical and psychiatric elites for the untoward effects of their "dynamic nominalism" on individual lives. Such arbitrary categories create new natural "kinds" of people (e.g., perverts, multiple personalities and so on) that serve larger political, cultural and moral purposes and change with historical contingencies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hacking|first=Ian|title=Making Up People|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v28/n16/ian-hacking/making-up-people|publisher=London Review of Books, 28 (16): 23-26, 17 August 2006|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609150150/http://www.lrb.co.uk/v28/n16/ian-hacking/making-up-people|archive-date=9 June 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hacking|first=Ian|title=Making Up People (full text)|url=http://generation-online.org/c/fcbiopolitics2.htm|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306133122/http://www.generation-online.org/c/fcbiopolitics2.htm|archive-date=6 March 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
According to the case history reports in the older psychiatric literature that formed the basis of Noll's parody, the condition starts with a key event in [[childhood]] that causes the experience of blood injury or the ingestion of blood to be exciting. After [[puberty]], the excitement is experienced as [[sexual arousal]]. Throughout [[adolescence]] and [[adulthood]], blood, its presence, and its consumption can also stimulate a sense of power and control. Noll speculated that Renfield's syndrome begins with [[autovampirism]] and then progresses to the consumption of the blood of other creatures.<ref name=cl>{{cite news |first=Katherine |last=Ramsland |authorlink=Katherine Ramsland |title=Renfield's Syndrome |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/serial_killers/weird/vampires/7.html |quote=Psychiatrists are aware that there exists a behavior known as "clinical vampirism," which is a syndrome involving the delusion of actually being a vampire and feeling the need for blood. This arises not from fiction and film but from the erotic attraction to blood and the idea that it conveys certain powers, although the actual manifestation of the fantasy may be influenced by fiction. It develops through fantasies involving sexual excitement. |publisher=[[Crime Library]] |accessdate=2007-12-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218202138/http://www.crimelibrary.com/serial_killers/weird/vampires/7.html |archive-date=2007-12-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The usefulness of this diagnostic label remains in question.{{cn|date=September 2018}} Very few cases of the syndrome have been described, and the published reports that do exist refer to what has been proposed as Renfield's syndrome through the use of official psychiatric diagnostic categories such as [[schizophrenia]] or as a variety of [[paraphilia]].
== Psychiatric and forensic contexts == Very few cases of the syndrome have been described, and the published reports that do exist describe clinical vampirism as behaviors that are subsumed under more conventional psychiatric diagnostic categories such as [[schizophrenia]] or [[paraphilia]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jensen|first=HM|author2=Poulsen, HD|title=Auto-vampirism in schizophrenia|journal=Nordic Journal of Psychiatry|year=2002|volume=56|issue=1|pages=47–48|doi=10.1080/08039480252803918}}</ref> A case of vampirism in Turkey reported in 2012 was discussed as an unusual feature of a patient diagnosed with [[dissociative identity disorder]] and [[post-traumatic stress disorder]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sakarya|first=Direne|title="Vampirism" in a case of dissociative identity disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder|journal=Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics|year=2012|volume=81|issue=5|pages=322–323|doi=10.1159/000335930|display-authors=etal}}</ref> While not referencing the literature on Renfield's syndrome, two Irish psychiatrists surveyed the psychiatric literature on vampirism as evidence of a changing discourse in psychiatry from the narrative of case studies to the depersonalized discourse of checklist diagnostic criteria.<ref>{{cite journal|last=MacSuibhne, Seamus|first=Seamus|author2=Kelly, Brendan d.|title=Vampirism as Mental Illness: Myth, Madness and the Loss of Meaning in Psychiatry|journal=Social History of Medicine|year=2010|volume=24|issue=2|pages=445–460|doi=10.1093/shm/hkq055}}</ref>
A number of murderers have performed seemingly vampiric rituals upon their victims. [[Serial killer]]s [[Peter Kürten]] and [[Richard Trenton Chase]] were both called "[[vampires]]" in the [[tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]]s after they were discovered drinking the blood of the people they murdered. Similarly, in 1932, an unsolved murder case in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] was nicknamed the "[[Atlas Vampire|Vampire murder]]", due to the circumstances of the victim's death.<ref name=Stig1>{{cite book |last=Linnell |first=Stig |title=Stockholms spökhus och andra ruskiga ställen |origyear=1968 |year=1993 |publisher=Raben Prisma |isbn=91-518-2738-7 |pages=|language=sv}}</ref>Clinical vampirism in the context of criminal acts of violence, as well as "consensual" vampirism as a social ritual, have been extensively documented in the many works of Katharine Ramsland.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ramsland|first=Katharine|title=The Science of Vampires|year=2002|publisher=Berkley|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Ramsland|first=Katharine|title=Piercing the Darkness: Undercover with Vampires in America Today|year=1999|publisher=HarperTorch|location=New York}}</ref> Others have commented upon the psychiatric implications of "vampire cults" among adolescents.<ref>{{cite journal|last=White|first=M|author2=Omar, H|title=Vampirism, vampire cults and the teenager of today|journal=International Journal of Adolescent Medicine and Health|year=2010|volume=22|issue=2|pages=189–195}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Clinical lycanthropy]] * [[Energy vampire]] * [[Vampire lifestyle]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite journal | last1 = Prins | first1 = H | year = 1985 | title = Vampirism — A clinical condition | url = | journal = British Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 146 | issue = | pages = 666–668 | doi=10.1192/bjp.146.6.666 | pmid=4016482}} * Vanden Bergh, R. L., & Kelly, J. F. (1964). Vampirism: A review with new observations. Archives of General Psychiatry, 11, 543-547. * Yarbro, Chelsea Quinn. ''Apprehensions and Other Delusions.'' (Waterville, Maine: Five Star, 2003) {{ISBN missing|date=September 2018}} * Richard Noll: ''Vampires, Werewolves and Demons: Twentieth century reports in the psychiatric literature.'' Brunner/ Mazel, New York 1992, {{ISBN|0-87630-632-6}}.

revision.text:
The Codex Writers' Group (aka "Codex") is an online community of active speculative fiction writers. Codex was created in January 2004.
== History and Membership Requirements ==
Codex was created in January 2004 by Luc Reid, a member of [[Orson Scott Card]]'s 2001 Literary Boot Camp.<ref> {{cite web |date=August 2003 | url =http://hatrack.com/writers/news/lucreid.shtml | title = Former Bootcampers Published: Luc Reid | accessdate = April 2008 }}</ref> The focus of the group is on writers in the early stages of their careers.<ref> {{cite web |date=January 2008 | url =http://www.codexwriters.com | title =Codex Writers Home Page, Membership Requirements | accessdate = April 2008 }}</ref> The forum uses the phrase 'neo-pro', which they define as "writers who've had at least one professional publication and/or participated in one of the top by-audition-only workshops, but who have not yet sold a great many stories or a number of books.".<ref> {{cite web |date=July 2011 | url =http://www.codexwriters.com/faq/ | title =Codex FAQ | accessdate = July 2011 }}</ref>
== Notable Codexians ==
The following Codexians have won major awards and/or have books on shelves. A more comprehensive listing of publications by Codex Writers can be found at the [http://www.codexwriters.com/library/ Codex Library Website].
* Steve Bein, author of the "Fated Blades" series [https://web.archive.org/web/20131126235243/http://philosofiction.com/styled-3/index.html] * John Brown, author of the ''Dark God'' series [summer 2009] * [[Tobias S. Buckell]], author of ''Crystal Rain'', ''Ragamuffin'', and ''[[Sly Mongoose]]'' * [[Aliette de Bodard]], author of the Obsidian and Blood books, Nebula and Locus Award winner. * Nancy Fulda, creator of [http://anthologybuilder.com AnthologyBuilder.com] * [[David Macinnis Gill]], author of ''[[Invisible Sun (novel)|InvisibleSun]]'', ''[[Black Hole Sun (novel)|Black Hole Sun]]'', and ''[[Soul Enchilada (novel)|Soul Enchilada]]'' * [[Jim C. Hines]], author of the ''Goblin Quest'' series * Elaine Isaak, author of ''The Singer's Crown'' and ''The Eunuch's Heir'' * Sharon Joss, author of the ''Hand of Fate'' series and ''Stars That Make Dark Heaven Light'' * [[Sara King]], author of the "After Earth" series <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apexbookcompany.com/apex-online/2008/02/sara-king/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090410125027/http://www.apexbookcompany.com/apex-online/2008/02/sara-king/ |archivedate=2009-04-10 |df= }}</ref> * [[Alethea Kontis]], NYTimes bestselling author of ''The Dark-Hunter Companion'', ''[http://www.aletheakontis.com/alphaoops/ AlphaOops: The Day Z Went First]'' and ''Beauty & Dynamite'' * James Maxey, author of the ''Bitterwood'' series * Judson Roberts, author of the ''Strongbow Saga'' series * [[Diana Rowland]], author of the ''Demon'' series (Mark of the Demon [Bantam, June 2009], Blood of the Demon [Bantam, February 2010], Secrets of the Demon [DAW, January 2011]) and the forthcoming ''White Trash Zombie'' series [DAW 2011] * [[Lawrence M. Schoen]], author of the ''Amazing Conroy'' series of stories, and founder of the [[Klingon Language Institute]] * Ken Scholes, author of ''The Psalms of Isaak'' series [Jan 2009] * [[Edmund R. Schubert]], editor of ''[[Orson Scott Card's InterGalactic Medicine Show]]'' ([[IGMS]]), and ''How To Write Magical Words: A Writer's Companion''
Codexians whose work has been or will be published in the [[Writers of the Future]] anthologies include Stewart C Baker, Steve Bein, Aliette de Bodard, Matt Dovey, Scott Roberts, Eric James Stone, Ken Scholes, Diana Rowland, David Goldman, Sharon Joss, Michael Livingston, Floris Kleijne, Andrew Gudgel, Lon Prater, William Katz, Brad Beaulieu, Luc Reid, Matt Champine, Tom Pendergrass, Robert Defendi, Joy Marchand (writing as Joy Remy), Matt Rotundo, and Jim Hines.<ref> {{cite web | year = 2007 | url = http://www.writersofthefuture.com/awards.htm | title = Writers of the Future Contest Winners, 1985-2006 | accessdate = April 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080501101544/http://www.writersofthefuture.com/awards.htm | archivedate = 2008-05-01 | df = }} </ref>
== External links == * [http://www.codexwriters.com Codex Writers Group Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080516083506/http://www.codexwriters.com/blog.htm Codex Mega Blog] * [http://www.codexwriters.com/Map/default.asp World Map showing locations of Codex Members] * [http://www.codexwriters.com/library/books.asp Books written by members of Codex] * [http://www.codexwriters.com/library/magazines.asp Magazine articles written by members of Codex] * [http://anthologybuilder.com AnthologyBuilder.com]
{{SpecFicWorkshops}}

revision.comment: programming implementation
revision.text: {{for|people from the city of Cracow|Kraków}} {{no footnotes|date=May 2015}} In [[astronomy|astronomical]] and [[geodesy|geodetic]] calculations, '''Cracovians''' are a clerical convenience introduced in the 1930s by [[Tadeusz Banachiewicz]] for solving systems of [[linear equation]]s by hand. Such systems can be written as ''Ax'' = ''b'' in [[matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] notation where ''x'' and ''b'' are column vectors and the evaluation of ''b'' requires the multiplication of the rows of ''A'' by the vector ''x''. Cracovians introduced the idea of using the [[matrix transpose|transpose]] of ''A'', ''A''T, and multiplying the columns of ''A''T by the column ''x''. This amounts to the definition of a new type of [[matrix multiplication]] denoted here by '∧'. Thus ''x'' ∧ ''A''T = ''b'' = ''Ax''. The Cracovian product of two matrices, say ''A'' and ''B'', is defined by ''A'' ∧ ''B'' = ''B''T''A'', where ''B''T and ''A'' are assumed compatible for the common ([[Arthur Cayley|Cayley]]) type of matrix multiplication. Since (''AB'')T = ''B''T''A''T, the products (''A'' ∧ ''B'') ∧ ''C'' and ''A'' ∧ (''B'' ∧ ''C'') will generally be different; thus, Cracovian multiplication is non-[[associativity|associative]]. Cracovians are an example of a [[quasigroup]]. Cracovians adopted a column-row convention for designating individual elements as opposed to the standard row-column convention of matrix analysis. This made manual multiplication easier, as one needed to follow two parallel columns (instead of a vertical column and a horizontal row in the matrix notation.) It also sped up computer calculations, because both factors' elements were used in a similar order, which was more compatible with the [[sequential access]] memory in computers of those times — mostly [[magnetic tape data storage|magnetic tape memory]] and [[drum memory]]. Use of Cracovians in astronomy faded as computers with bigger [[random access memory]] came into general use. Any modern reference to them is in connection with their non-associative multiplication. ==Programming implementation== In [[R programming language|R]] the desired effect can be achieved via the crossprod() function. Specifically, the Cracovian product of matrices ''A'' and ''B'' can be obtained as crossprod(B, A). ==References== *Banachiewicz, T. (1955). ''Vistas in Astronomy'', vol. 1, issue 1, pp 200–206. *Herget, Paul; (1948, reprinted 1962). ''The computation of orbits, University of Cincinnati Observatory'' (privately published). [[Asteroid]] [[1751 Herget|1751]] is named after the author. * Kocinski, J. (2004). ''Cracovian Algebra'', Nova Science Publishers. [[Category:Astrometry]] [[Category:History of astronomy]] [[Category:Matrix theory]]

revision.comment: Alter: url, title. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]]; [[Category:Critical theory]].
revision.text:
{{short description|Variant of social science that seeks to interpret and change the world}} {{refimprove|date=October 2016}} {{History of geography sidebar}} '''Critical geography''' is theoretically informed geographical scholarship that seeks for [[social justice]], [[Emancipation|liberation]], and [[Left-wing politics|leftist politics]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5gCHckKszz0C&pg=PA1974&dq=The+dictionary+of+human+geography#v=onepage&q=The%20dictionary%20of%20human%20geography&f=false|title=The Dictionary of Human Geography|last=Gregory|first=Derek|last2=Johnston|first2=Ron|last3=Pratt|first3=Geraldine|last4=Watts|first4=Michael|last5=Whatmore|first5=Sarah|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=2011|isbn=9781444359954|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> Critical geography is also used as an umbrella term for [[Marxist geography|Marxist]], [[Feminist geography|feminist]], [[Postmodernism|postmodern]], [[Post-structuralism|poststructural]], [[queer]], [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]], and [[Activism|activist]] geography.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780080449104002637|title=International Encyclopedia of Human Geography|last=Best|first=U.|publisher=Elsevier|year=2009|isbn=9780080449104|editor-last=Kitchin|editor-first=Rob|location=Oxford|pages=345–357|editor-last2=Thrift|editor-first2=Nigel}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Castree|first=Noel|year=2000|title=Professionalisation, Activism, and the University: Whither 'Critical Geography'?|journal=Environment and Planning A|language=en|volume=32|issue=6|pages=955–970|doi=10.1068/a3263}}</ref>
Critical geography is one variant of [[Critical theory|critical social science and humanities]] that adopt [[Karl Marx|Marx]]’s thesis to interpret and change the world. Fay (1987) defines contemporary critical science as the effort to understand the [[oppression]] in a society and use this understanding to promote societal change and liberation.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Critical_social_science.html?id=5K98AAAAIAAJ|title=Critical social science: liberation and its limits|last=Fay|first=Brian|publisher=Cornell University Press|year=1987|isbn=9780801494581|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> Agger (1998) identifies a number of features of critical social theory practiced in fields like geography, which include: a rejection of [[positivism]]; an endorsement of the possibility of progress; a claim for the structural dynamics of [[Social dominance theory|domination]]; an argument that dominance derived from forms of false consciousness, ideology, and myth; a faith in the agency of everyday change and self-transformation and an attendant rejection of [[determinism]]; and a rejection of revolutionary expediency.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Critical_Social_Theories.html?id=eB-B6XercZoC|title=Critical Social Theories: An Introduction|last=Agger|first=Ben|publisher=Avalon Publishing|year=1988|isbn=9780813321745|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref>
== Origin == Critical geography in the Anglo-American world rooted in the '''radical geography''' that emerged in the early 1970s. Peet (2000) provides an overview of the evolution of radical and critical geography.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Peet|first=Richard|year=2000|title=Celebrating Thirty Years of Radical Geography|journal=Environment and Planning A|language=en|volume=32|issue=6|pages=951–953|doi=10.1068/a32202}}</ref> In the early 1970s, radical geographers tried to transform the scope of the discipline of geography by responding to the great issues of the time - civil rights, environmental pollution, and war. From the mid- to late-1970s saw ascending critiques of the [[quantitative revolution]] and the adoption of [[Marxism|Marxist]] approach. The 1980s is marked by fissures between humanistic, feminist and Marxist streams, and a reversal of structural excess. In the late 1980s, critical geography emerged and gradually became a self-identified field.
Although closely related, critical geography and radical geography are not interchangeable. Critical geography has two crucial departures from radical geography: (1) a rejection of the structural excess of [[Marxism]], in accordance with the [[Postmodernism|post-modern turn]]; and (2) an increasing interest in culture and [[Social representation|representation]], in contrast to radical geography’s focus on the economy.<ref name=":0" /> Peet (2000) notices a rapprochement between critical and radical geography after heated debate in the 1990s.<ref name=":2" /> Nevertheless, Castree (2000) posits that critical and radical geography entail different commitments.<ref name=":1" /> He contends that the eclipse of radical geography indicates the professionalization and academicization of Left geography, and therefore worries about the loss of the "radical" tradition.<ref name=":1" />
== Common themes == As a consequence of the [[Postmodernism|post-modern turn]], critical geography doesn’t have a unified commitment. Hubbard, Kitchin, Bartley, and Fuller (2002) asserts that critical geography has a diverse [[epistemology]], [[ontology]], and [[methodology]], and does not have a distinctive theoretical identity.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=71SvAwAAQBAJ&pg=PP1&dq=thinking+geographically#v=onepage&q=thinking%20geographically&f=false|title=Thinking Geographically: Space, Theory and Contemporary Human Geography|last=Hubbard|first=Phil|last2=Bartley|first2=Brendan|last3=Fuller|first3=Duncan|last4=Kitchin|first4=Rob|publisher=A&C Black|year=2002|isbn=9780567259882|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> Nonetheless, Blomley (2006) identifies six common themes of critical geography,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Blomley|first=Nicholas|year=2006|title=Uncritical critical geography?|journal=Progress in Human Geography|language=en|volume=30|issue=1|pages=87–94|doi=10.1191/0309132506ph593pr}}</ref> encompassing: # '''A commitment to theory and a rejection of [[empiricism]].''' Critical geographers consciously deploy theories of some form, but they draw from a variety of theoretical wells, such as [[political economy]], [[governmentality]], [[feminism]], [[anti-racism]], and [[anti-imperialism]]. # '''A commitment to reveal the processes that produce [[Social inequality|inequalities]]'''. Critical geographers seek to unveil [[Power (social and political)|power]], uncover [[Social inequality|inequality]], expose resistance, and cultivate liberating politics and [[social change]]s. # '''An emphasis on [[Social representation|representation]] as a means of domination and resistance'''. A common focus of critical geography is to study how representations of space sustain power; or on the contrary, how representations of space can be used to challenge power. # '''An optimistic faith in the power of critical scholarship'''. Critical geographers believe that scholarship can be used to resist the dominant representations, and scholar can undo power domination and free the oppressed. There exists an implicit confidence in the power of critical scholarship to reach the ignorant, and in the capacities of people to defeat alienation by means of reflexive self-education. # '''A commitment to progressive practices'''. Critical geographers want to make a difference. They claim to be united with [[social movement]]s and activists with commitments to [[social justice]]. The relationship between critical geography and [[activism]] has been much debated.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Radical_Theory_critical_Praxis.html?id=zGabDAEACAAJ|title=Radical Theory/critical Praxis: Making a Difference Beyond the Academy?|last=Fuller|first=Duncan|last2=Kitchin|first2=Rob|publisher=Praxis (e)Press|year=2004|isbn=9780973456103|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> # '''An understanding of [[space]] as a critical tool.''' Critical geographers pay special attention to how spatial arrangements and representations can be used to produce [[oppression]] and [[Social inequality|inequality]]. Critical geographers identify to varying degrees how space can be used as both a veil and tool of power.
== Critiques == A few important questions remain unsolved in critical geography.<ref name=":0" /> The first one is that there has been relatively limited discussion over the shared commitments of critical geographers, with a few exceptions such as Harvey (2000).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Spaces_of_Hope.html?id=W00VHZg3u2MC|title=Spaces of Hope|last=Harvey|first=David|publisher=University of California Press|year=2000|isbn=9780520225787|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> The question such as "what are geographers critical of", and "to what end" needs to be answered.<ref name=":0" /> Barnes (2002) comments that critical geographers are better at providing explanatory diagnoses than offering anticipatory-utopian imaginations to reconfigure the world.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barnes|first=Trevor J.|year=2002|title=Critical notes on economic geography from an aging radical. Or radical notes on economic geography from a critical age|url=https://ojs.unbc.ca/index.php/acme/article/view/687|journal=ACME: An International Journal for Critical Geographies|language=en|volume=1|issue=1|pages=8–14|issn=1492-9732|via=}}</ref>
The second question concerns the institutionalization of critical geography. Even though critical geographers conceive themselves as rebels and outsiders, critical thinking has become prevalent in geography.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/arts/maps-and-chaps-7142744|title=Maps and Chaps|last=Byles|first=Jeff|date=2001-07-31|work=Village Voice|access-date=2017-04-04}}</ref> Critical geography is now situated at the very heart of the discipline of geography.<ref name=":1" /> Some see institutionalization as a natural result of the analytical strength and insights of critical geography, while others fear that institutionalization has entailed cooperation.<ref name=":0" /> The question is whether critical geography still holds its commitment to political change.<ref name=":0" />
Lastly, as critical geography is practiced across the world, the insights of critical geographers outside the Anglophone world should be better acknowledged.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bialasiewicz|first=Luiza|year=2003|title=The Many Wor(l)ds of Difference and Dissent|journal=Antipode|language=en|volume=35|issue=1|pages=14–23|doi=10.1111/1467-8330.00299|issn=1467-8330}}</ref> In this regard, Mizuoka et al. (2005) offered an overview of Japanese critical geography praxis since the 1920s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mizuoka|first=Fujio|last2=Mizuuchi|first2=Toshio|last3=Hisatake|first3=Tetsuya|last4=Tsutsumi|first4=Kenji|last5=Fujita|first5=Tetsushi|year=2005|title=The Critical Heritage of Japanese Geography: Its Tortured Trajectory for Eight Decades|journal=Environment and Planning D: Society and Space|language=en|volume=23|issue=3|pages=453–473|doi=10.1068/d2204r}}</ref> In addition, critical geography should also forge stronger linkage with critical scholars in other disciplines.
== See also == * [[Activism]] * [[Critical theory]] * [[Feminist geography]] * [[Left-wing politics]] * [[Marxist geography]] * [[Postmodernism]] * [[Post-structuralism]] * [[Quantitative revolution]] * [[Queer theory]] == References== <references /> == Further reading == * Blomley, Nicholas (2006). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1191/0309132506ph593pr "Uncritical critical geography?"]. ''Progress in Human Geography''. '''30''' (1): 87–94. {{doi|10.1191/0309132506ph593pr}}.
* Blunt, Alison; Wills, Jane (2000). [https://books.google.com/books/about/Dissident_Geographies.html?id=DgodHQ6rcLkC ''Dissident Geographies: An Introduction to Radical Ideas and Practice'']. Prentice Hall. {{ISBN|9780582294899}}.
* [[Noel Castree|Castree, Noel]] (2000). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1068/a3263 "Professionalisation, Activism, and the University: Whither 'Critical Geography'?"]. ''Environment and Planning A''. '''32''' (6): 955–970. {{doi|10.1068/a3263}}.
* [[Noel Castree|Castree, Noel]]; [[Derek Gregory|Gregory, Derek]] (2006). [https://books.google.com/books?id=oj7xiGby2LAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=david+harvey+a+critical+reader&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiO1fmGy__SAhWe2YMKHaz1BWUQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=david%20harvey%20a%20critical%20reader&f=false ''David Harvey: A Critical Reader'']. John Wiley & Sons. {{ISBN|9780470775318}}.
* [[Pete Richardson|Peet, Richard]] (2000). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1068/a32202 "Celebrating Thirty Years of Radical Geography"]. ''Environment and Planning A''. '''32''' (6): 951–953. {{doi|10.1068/a32202}}.
